slides.title: Welcome to Celestial Mechanics
slides.content:
# Introduction to Celestial Mechanics

Welcome to **Celestial Mechanics** - the mathematics of motion in space!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Kepler's Laws** - Orbital motion
- **Newton's Gravity** - The fundamental force
- **Orbital Elements** - Describing orbits
- **Perturbations** - Gravitational influences
- **Space Missions** - Navigating the cosmos

> **Fun Fact:** NASA uses the same orbital mechanics that Kepler discovered 400 years ago!

slides.title: Kepler's First Law
slides.content:
# Kepler's First Law

## Statement:
Planets orbit the Sun in ellipses, with the Sun at one focus.

## Ellipse Terminology:
- Semi-major axis (a): Half the long axis
- Semi-minor axis (b): Half the short axis
- Focus: Off-center point
- Eccentricity (e): How elongated (0 = circle, 1 = parabola)

## Eccentricity Formula:
```
e = sqrt(1 - b^2/a^2)
```

## Solar System:
| Object | Eccentricity |
|--------|-------------|
| Earth | 0.017 |
| Mars | 0.093 |
| Pluto | 0.249 |
| Halley's Comet | 0.967 |

slides.title: Kepler's Second Law
slides.content:
# Kepler's Second Law

## Statement:
A line from planet to Sun sweeps equal areas in equal times.

## Implications:
- Faster near perihelion (closest)
- Slower near aphelion (farthest)

## Conservation:
- Angular momentum conserved
- L = m x v x r = constant

## Earth Example:
- Perihelion: January (~147 million km)
- Aphelion: July (~152 million km)
- Faster in January!

slides.title: Kepler's Third Law
slides.content:
# Kepler's Third Law

## Statement:
The square of the orbital period is proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis.

```
T^2 = (4*pi^2 / GM) x a^3
```

## Simplified (AU and years):
```
T^2 = a^3
```
where T is in years, a is in AU.

## Examples:
| Planet | a (AU) | T (years) |
|--------|--------|----------|
| Earth | 1.0 | 1.0 |
| Mars | 1.52 | 1.88 |
| Jupiter | 5.2 | 11.9 |
| Saturn | 9.5 | 29.5 |

slides.title: Newton's Law of Gravitation
slides.content:
# Newton's Universal Gravitation

## The Law:
```
F = G x M x m / r^2
```

## Constants:
- G = 6.674 x 10^-11 N m^2/kg^2

## Key Insights:
- Inverse square law
- Attractive only
- Acts on all masses

## Derived Quantities:

| Quantity | Formula |
|----------|--------|
| Orbital velocity | sqrt(GM/r) |
| Escape velocity | sqrt(2GM/r) |
| Gravitational PE | -GMm/r |

## Newton's Contribution:
- Explained WHY Kepler's laws work
- Predicted orbital mechanics

slides.title: Orbital Elements
slides.content:
# Keplerian Orbital Elements

## Six Elements Define an Orbit:

| Element | Symbol | Meaning |
|---------|--------|--------|
| Semi-major axis | a | Orbit size |
| Eccentricity | e | Orbit shape |
| Inclination | i | Tilt from reference |
| Longitude of ascending node | Omega | Where orbit crosses up |
| Argument of periapsis | omega | Orientation in plane |
| True anomaly | nu | Position in orbit |

## Alternative:
- Mean anomaly (M) instead of true
- Time of perihelion passage

## Uses:
- Spacecraft navigation
- Asteroid tracking
- Satellite operations

slides.title: Orbit Types
slides.content:
# Types of Orbits

## By Energy:

| Orbit | Eccentricity | Shape |
|-------|-------------|-------|
| Circular | e = 0 | Circle |
| Elliptical | 0 < e < 1 | Ellipse |
| Parabolic | e = 1 | Parabola |
| Hyperbolic | e > 1 | Hyperbola |

## Bound vs Unbound:
- Elliptical: Bound to body
- Parabolic/Hyperbolic: Escape

## Earth Satellite Orbits:
| Type | Altitude | Period |
|------|----------|--------|
| LEO | 200-2000 km | ~90 min |
| GEO | 35,786 km | 24 hours |
| HEO | Variable | Variable |

slides.title: Orbital Maneuvers
slides.content:
# Orbital Maneuvers

## Hohmann Transfer:
- Most efficient for circular-to-circular
- Two burns
- Uses tangential velocity changes

## Delta-V:
- Change in velocity required
- Key mission parameter
- Limited by fuel mass

## Common Maneuvers:

| Maneuver | Purpose |
|----------|--------|
| Hohmann | Transfer between orbits |
| Bi-elliptic | Very large changes |
| Gravity assist | Free delta-v from planets |
| Aerobraking | Use atmosphere |

## Example Delta-V:
- Earth to LEO: ~9.4 km/s
- LEO to Moon: ~4 km/s

slides.title: Gravity Assists
slides.content:
# Gravity Assist (Slingshot)

## Concept:
- Use planet's gravity and motion
- Gain or lose velocity
- Free propulsion!

## How It Works:
- Spacecraft approaches planet
- Bent by gravity
- Leaves with changed velocity

## Famous Examples:
- Voyager: Used Jupiter, Saturn
- Cassini: Venus, Earth, Jupiter
- Parker Solar Probe: Venus (7 times)

## Conservation:
- Momentum conserved in system
- Planet slowed infinitesimally
- Spacecraft sped up significantly

slides.title: Perturbations
slides.content:
# Orbital Perturbations

## Causes:
- Other gravitating bodies
- Non-spherical central body
- Atmospheric drag
- Solar radiation pressure

## Effects:
- Orbit changes over time
- Precession of orbit plane
- Apsidal precession

## Earth Satellite Examples:

| Cause | Effect |
|-------|--------|
| Moon/Sun | Plane precession |
| J2 (Earth bulge) | Node precession |
| Drag (LEO) | Orbit decay |

## Lagrange Points:
- Stable equilibrium points
- L1, L2, L4, L5 used for missions

slides.title: Tides
slides.content:
# Tidal Forces

## Cause:
- Differential gravity across a body
- Near side pulled more than far side

## Effects:

| Effect | Example |
|--------|--------|
| Ocean tides | Moon on Earth |
| Tidal locking | Moon to Earth |
| Tidal heating | Io, Europa |
| Orbital decay | Moon receding |

## Roche Limit:
- Distance where tides break a body apart
- Inside: Rings form
- Outside: Moon survives

## Tidal Locking:
- Rotation period = Orbital period
- Moon always shows same face

slides.title: N-Body Problem
slides.content:
# The N-Body Problem

## Definition:
Predict motion of N gravitating bodies.

## Solvability:
- 2-body: Exact solution (Kepler orbits)
- 3-body: No general solution
- N-body: Numerical methods only

## Chaos:
- Small changes in initial conditions
- Large changes in outcome
- Long-term prediction limited

## Methods:
- Numerical integration
- Perturbation theory
- Computer simulations

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Celestial Mechanics Summary

## Kepler's Laws:
1. Elliptical orbits
2. Equal areas, equal times
3. T^2 ~ a^3

## Newton's Gravity:
- F = GMm/r^2
- Explains Kepler's laws

## Orbital Elements:
- Six parameters define orbit
- a, e, i, Omega, omega, nu

## Maneuvers:
| Type | Use |
|------|-----|
| Hohmann | Orbit transfer |
| Gravity assist | Free velocity |

## Perturbations:
- Other bodies, drag, radiation
- Lagrange points for stability

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Celestial Mechanics!
